ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We watched recorded lectures as a sort of preparation for our classes, but the actual classes themselves were synchronous and more akin to a seminar--participation was always encouraged.
Also watched pre-recorded lectures
Recorded lecture and virtual synchronous seminar
Recorded lecture, live meetings that were part lecture and part discussion
Recorded lecture + virtual discussion
Recorded lectures assigned for homework, in person leminar with section once a week
We watched pre-recorded lectures in preparation for class, which was used as a seminar/section time.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how the Bible was constructed, how it was initially viewed, etc. It really is the sort of class where you learn as much as the work you put in.
Attention to detail, commitment to course work (no slacking here!), and understanding of religions at large
I learned all about the Hebrew Bible, biblical exegesis, and how to read the Bible without making assumptions about what the text is and what it should be.

Hebrew Bible historical context, different critical approaches to Hebrew Bible study (in particular source criticism and redaction criticism), reading and analyzing the Bible both as literature and as the story of a people group
This course developed my critical reading and thinking skills.
Read the whole Hebrew Bible, which I had never done before. Also got to read excerpts from the Epic of Gilgamesh and teh Enuma Elish which was great.
I read the Old Testament of the Bible and learned about the historical context and various interpretations of its stories

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Best lecture class. Ever. The size this semester more of a "leminar," which facilitated meaningful learning. Professor Hayes is a genius.

The class has straightforward exams and a very fun final paper. The assignments are not stressful. I enjoyed the structure of assignments, but also the emphasis on readings and discussion questions, which were always worthwhile.

I'm not sure if this is possible, but it might be nice not to have the final paper due the night before the final exam. I know that this felt like a lot to handle in a few consecutive days, so if scheduling a different time is possible, that would be great.

Good readings and pacing. Lectures and class discussions complemented each other. Class prepared us well for exams and final paper. Managed to organize a big topic well, and cover many sides of it in just a few weeks.

While the recorded lectures were an effective way to review the reading materials before the live discussion, they were so jam-packed full of important information that it was difficult to filter through when taking notes. As a result, I would often have to pause the lecture many times in order to take notes, which ended up taking a lot more time than was expected. Moving forward, I'd suggest that if the recorded lectures will continually be used, the discussion session should use powerpoints (or other visual aids) more to organize and summarize the lecture information as the class goes into deeper discussion.
I thought that it did a good job of introducing the material and making it accessible to a wide range of students.

Professor Hayes knows alot, alot, alot and is very good at communicating the things she knows. The syllabus is  really well organized and timed. I think I would have enjoyed more literary and symbolic analysis-- it was centered on the historical context and I think part of what attracted to me to take a class on the bible was the question of what about the text makes it still so appealing/meaningful today, which I don't feel we really addressed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Expectation of preparedness each class. Everyone participates-- skits, role plays, summaries, etc.

Professor Hayes was really adept at using Zoom (even if she doesn't think so herself), and it was great to be in discussion sections so often. It might be nice to switch up the discussion groups, though, since I was with the same group of students for the entire semester. I would have enjoyed getting to know other students, especially as a sophomore learning from home this semester.
Breakout room discussions were helpful. Having the audio lectures as well as the textbook sections was also helpful.
I liked the combination of prerecorded and synchronous lectures.

I think that it transitioned very well to the online forum. One thing is that I think it could have been a once a week live seminar, as opposed to twice a week in addition to the online lectures-- mostly because it is exhausting to be attending that many online lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would most definitely recommend this course. It's probably one of the best courses I've taken at Yale. Professor Hayes is an excellent instructor, and knows how to conduct a course so that you have to be engaged.
100% TAKE! A disservice if you don't...

Absolutely. This is one of the best classes that I have taken at Yale. 

If you aren't religious, you might feel like you don't belong in this course. However, this class is more about the Bible as literature than it is about the Bible as religion, and it discusses the creation and evolution of the text in the context of history. It is a fascinating exploration of the texts that helped shape western culture, from our laws to our customs. 

You should consider that the class is quite a lot of work when you factor in meeting times, prerecorded lectures, and readings. All the work is tremendously worthwhile, but it is a lot to handle at times.

This is a GREAT class. You not only read and learn what the Bible actually says, but you develop a deep understanding of the complex historical factors that influenced the biblical authors. The Bible plays a really large role in American society and in every day lifesomething I appreciated more and more as I was able to actually identify more obscure biblical references in tv shows or in readings for other classes. Regardless of your personal religious beliefs, you'll benefit from knowing more about the Bible. That being said, it is a decent amount of work. You can't really skip a lot of the readings and the final paper and final exam is a tough combination at the end. I'm still incredibly glad I took the class, so if you're willing to do the work and the readings, I could not recommend it more. Professor Hayes is absolutely brilliant and a really wonderful instructor. Take any class that you can with her.

YES! I'm a junior who takes a lot of classes about the Bible, and this is my favorite so far. No matter how little or how much you know about the Hebrew Bible, you'll still learn something from this class.  You'll learn history, a little bit of literary criticism, and interpretive methods for your own study of the Bible.
I would recommend it to students interested in studying the bible.

If you are really interested in reading the bible, this class is great, especially if your interest is historical or religious-studies based, and if you want to pursue the study of the bible/ancient literatures beyond this. If you are more interested in understanding the bible's literary influence, or how it has been read in later contexts, I don't think this class is a must-take.
Absolutely! I came into this class with absolutely no knowledge of religious studies, and I've gained such a valuable perspective on near-eastern history and the Abrahamic religions.
